turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: We will hear arguments next in 1750, Stump against Sparkman.
Mr. Fruechtenicht you may proceed whenever you are ready.

turn.speaker: george_e_fruechtenicht
turn.label: Mr. George E. Fruechtenicht
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, the Court please.
As the documents indicate, I represent the Harold Stump petitioner in this matter.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Could you raise your voice a little, counsel?

turn.speaker: george_e_fruechtenicht
turn.label: Mr. George E. Fruechtenicht
turn.text: Yes, sir.
I represent Herald Stump and I would like to identify my client.
He is the Circuit Court Judge of the DeKalb County Indiana.
The DeKalb County lies on the North Eastern part of the state just next to Ohio about 30,000 residents occupy the county.
County of Cedar (ph), Auburn, town of about six thousand people that is where the Courthouse is.
Judge lives there, that is where he works.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: No, there is only a single Judge in that county?

turn.speaker: george_e_fruechtenicht
turn.label: Mr. George E. Fruechtenicht
turn.text: Yes.
The action occurred your Honor in 1971 and at that time he was the sole Court of General Jurisdiction.
He has been elected four times and is now serving his 20th year.
His father Walter Stump serves has a Circuit Court Judge on the same bench for 12 years before him.
Judge Stump is a Judge of a considerable experience and I will indicate to this Court, a Judge of the highest integrity.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: It is a important issue, Garcia is the scope of this jurisdiction.

turn.speaker: george_e_fruechtenicht
turn.label: Mr. George E. Fruechtenicht
turn.text: That is correct your honor.

The issue, the principal issue is what is a Doctrine of Judicial Immunity should be applied to and approval signed by Judge Stump of a petition filed by the mother and sole guardian of the 15 year old girl to have surgery performed upon her ,that surgery was a tubal ligation.

The larger issue I would submit to this Court would be whether the doctrine of judicial immunity should be permitted to be, in my view, diluted and altered by the pronouncements of the opinion of the Seventh Circuit Court of Appeal.

The context in which the matter was presented or is has presented, the factual background, so, far as the Judge is concerned is as follows: the mother Ora McFarlin, determined that apparently because of facts set out in a petition, her daughter 15-years old should have tubal ligation.
The petition speaks for itself, it set forth in the brief of the respondents along with the approval.
Briefly, it suggests or alleges under oath that the daughter is sexually promiscuous that she has been uncontrollable, that the mother is concerned.

Obviously, that the daughter is going to become pregnant and that for the best interest of the child, she asks that the Court approve a petition by the mother to have tubal ligation performed upon her.

When that petition was presented to the Court by the mother and her attorney, the Court then was required to make a primary threshold decision and that was whether or not he had jurisdiction to approve that petition.
I submit to the Court and made this decision as Courts of General Jurisdiction in every county, every day throughout this country must make in matters of this particular type.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: You mean, how many of these do we have in the country?

turn.speaker: george_e_fruechtenicht
turn.label: Mr. George E. Fruechtenicht
turn.text: I beg your pardon.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: How many cases do we have we in the country, where a mother has for a daughter --

turn.speaker: george_e_fruechtenicht
turn.label: Mr. George E. Fruechtenicht
turn.text: I am talking about -- Courts of General Jurisdiction your Honor required to make decision of this particular type in every county throughout.

At that time the Court realized that he had a General Jurisdiction statute under which he functioned and that General Jurisdiction statute in broad language, enacted by the legislature of the city of Indiana and to this date unamended, indicates that he shall have original exclusive jurisdiction in all cases that law and equity and whatsoever and he shall have jurisdiction of all other causes, matters and proceedings.
Also in existence of that.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Is there not --.

turn.speaker: george_e_fruechtenicht
turn.label: Mr. George E. Fruechtenicht
turn.text: I beg your pardon.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Isn't there some limitation on that, if it is not the assigned to some other Court?

turn.speaker: george_e_fruechtenicht
turn.label: Mr. George E. Fruechtenicht
turn.text: I am sorry, yes sir your Honor.
Thereof, if it is not conferred were exclusive jurisdiction thereof is not conferred by law upon some other Court board or office and that is correct.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: He would not have probate jurisdiction for example.

turn.speaker: george_e_fruechtenicht
turn.label: Mr. George E. Fruechtenicht
turn.text: He would.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: He would?

turn.speaker: george_e_fruechtenicht
turn.label: Mr. George E. Fruechtenicht
turn.text: Yes, he would in this case.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: But there would be some jurisdiction that he would not have.

turn.speaker: george_e_fruechtenicht
turn.label: Mr. George E. Fruechtenicht
turn.text: I cannot think of it, except where jurisdiction has been specifically proscribed whether has been a bar either by common law or by legislation a Court of General Jurisdiction in a county has hat it all your Honor.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Are there are no other layers of Courts in the --.

turn.speaker: george_e_fruechtenicht
turn.label: Mr. George E. Fruechtenicht
turn.text: None.
He has criminal jurisdiction, juvenile jurisdiction, he has civil jurisdiction, he has the general Jurisdiction overall causes, matters and proceedings.

With this in mind, also there were not jurisdictional statutes in existence but there was statutes in existence on the State of the Indiana at that time which in general terms permitted parents to consent to medical treatment on behalf of their minor children.
There are two such statutes, one for people who are incompetent by reason of minority and insanity, mental illness, imbecility, idiocies, senility, habitual drunkenness and the like.
And the other is simply any person who is the parent of the child shall be competent to give consent to and contract from medical or hospital care or treatment of such child including surgery.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: What if --

turn.speaker: george_e_fruechtenicht
turn.label: Mr. George E. Fruechtenicht
turn.text: I beg your pardon.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: What if Mrs. McFarlin had presented a piece of paper to your client, the Judge and said my daughter is incompetent, she is a kleptomaniac, she has done a lot of shoplifting and I want your approval to have her right hand chopped off and the Judge had signed the approval and that surgery had been performed, would your argument --.

turn.speaker: george_e_fruechtenicht
turn.label: Mr. George E. Fruechtenicht
turn.text: Your Honor, Judge Swagger (ph), I must remark on the apparel, he said both of her hands got off, when we are arguing in the Court of Appeals.
That would not be an operation your Honor.
I would suggest that Court would even consider especially a Court such Judge Stump.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Well, assume that this Court did do that.

turn.speaker: george_e_fruechtenicht
turn.label: Mr. George E. Fruechtenicht
turn.text: If he did do that.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: He has it, you say that a parent can have surgery done on behalf of the child and here let us assume in my case, that the Court had order that operation on that representation by the parent.
Would you be making the same argument?

turn.speaker: george_e_fruechtenicht
turn.label: Mr. George E. Fruechtenicht
turn.text: If I may respectfully suggest your Honor that assumption is going to lend, it is not going to, it is not your meaning to the issues.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Well I think it cast your argument.
If I may say so--

turn.speaker: george_e_fruechtenicht
turn.label: Mr. George E. Fruechtenicht
turn.text: It certainly does.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Well is there a statute in your state against mutilation, is there statutes in most states against the mutilation of the human body.

turn.speaker: george_e_fruechtenicht
turn.label: Mr. George E. Fruechtenicht
turn.text: If there is your Honor I am aware of it.
I am aware of it, in answers to your questions your Honor that would be in appropriate action on the part of the Judge.
It is certainly not before us.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Well you concede that this action was inappropriate.

turn.speaker: george_e_fruechtenicht
turn.label: Mr. George E. Fruechtenicht
turn.text: This statute your Honor is a medical care statute.
your premise was she was a kleptomaniac.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: That the mother said she was.

turn.speaker: george_e_fruechtenicht
turn.label: Mr. George E. Fruechtenicht
turn.text: Yes, certainly cutting off her hands is not going to improve her physically.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Well do you think this improved this trial physically, this operation?

turn.speaker: george_e_fruechtenicht
turn.label: Mr. George E. Fruechtenicht
turn.text: I think your Honor that decision was made and that except from the stand point improving her physically it was at least surgery.
And at least surgery on these circumstances is permitted by the statute and it is within the context of that statute that this particular approval was made.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, so, would it be in my hypothetical case.

turn.speaker: george_e_fruechtenicht
turn.label: Mr. George E. Fruechtenicht
turn.text: Then you are entitled that conclusion your Honor.
This is one that I most certainly do not conclude and I do not think that the Court of General Jurisdiction of this Court's experience would entertain such as petition.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But counsel, supposing the petition recited a different reason that said I want approval of amputation of the right arm.

turn.speaker: george_e_fruechtenicht
turn.label: Mr. George E. Fruechtenicht
turn.text: Your Honor.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Because it is malignant or something like that.

turn.speaker: george_e_fruechtenicht
turn.label: Mr. George E. Fruechtenicht
turn.text: Your Honor.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Yes.
The Judge would have jurisdiction on such a --

turn.speaker: george_e_fruechtenicht
turn.label: Mr. George E. Fruechtenicht
turn.text: Yes, he would.
There is no question about that.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: So, the question is whether he acted for the right reason or not.

turn.speaker: george_e_fruechtenicht
turn.label: Mr. George E. Fruechtenicht
turn.text: That is not the question, the final question your Honor is whether he had jurisdiction to act at all.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, did he have jurisdiction to decide the example that Justice Steward gives you?

turn.speaker: george_e_fruechtenicht
turn.label: Mr. George E. Fruechtenicht
turn.text: Of chopping off the hands.
In the final analysis, yes he would have jurisdiction to act.
Now what he would do I am suggesting however, in those certain chances is refuse.
He would refuse to consent.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But, your argument is that if he did give consent because he had jurisdiction, he would have judicial immunity.

turn.speaker: george_e_fruechtenicht
turn.label: Mr. George E. Fruechtenicht
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Is this an action at law or an equity?

turn.speaker: george_e_fruechtenicht
turn.label: Mr. George E. Fruechtenicht
turn.text: This was not action at law or in equity your Honor.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Then why did he choose --.

turn.speaker: george_e_fruechtenicht
turn.label: Mr. George E. Fruechtenicht
turn.text: He did not.
He got jurisdiction by virtue of the provisions of the General Jurisdiction statute, which permits him to have jurisdiction of all other matters, causes and proceedings.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well does that include admiralty.

turn.speaker: george_e_fruechtenicht
turn.label: Mr. George E. Fruechtenicht
turn.text: Yes, I would assume so, if there such a thing in DeKalb County Indiana, I think they have some streams there that are navigable.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Streams that are navigable.

turn.speaker: george_e_fruechtenicht
turn.label: Mr. George E. Fruechtenicht
turn.text: Yes, they do.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Streams that are navigable.
Stream, would you mean, a river.

turn.speaker: george_e_fruechtenicht
turn.label: Mr. George E. Fruechtenicht
turn.text: Yes, I believe that is defined by a law an alien law that can float.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, do they have jurisdiction over bankruptcy.

turn.speaker: george_e_fruechtenicht
turn.label: Mr. George E. Fruechtenicht
turn.text: No, that is federal a law.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: You and I both know that when use a general term, you do not mean everything.

turn.speaker: george_e_fruechtenicht
turn.label: Mr. George E. Fruechtenicht
turn.text: Of course not.
He has jurisdiction over receiver ships, the receiver ships those are in South East.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Could he entertain a petition of the man to have Mrs. John Dow sterilized.
Mrs. John Dow being no relation at all.

turn.speaker: george_e_fruechtenicht
turn.label: Mr. George E. Fruechtenicht
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Why not?

turn.speaker: george_e_fruechtenicht
turn.label: Mr. George E. Fruechtenicht
turn.text: I do not think that is jurisdiction your Honor.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Why not?

turn.speaker: george_e_fruechtenicht
turn.label: Mr. George E. Fruechtenicht
turn.text: Because there has to be some reason for him to be presented with the petition.
He cannot simply sit back and say this morning, I think I will have simply somebody sterilized.
The matter obviously must be presented to him.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: A petition was filed.

turn.speaker: george_e_fruechtenicht
turn.label: Mr. George E. Fruechtenicht
turn.text: By whom?

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: By John Jones, to have Mary Brown sterilized.

turn.speaker: george_e_fruechtenicht
turn.label: Mr. George E. Fruechtenicht
turn.text: Okay.
The petition, the petition would set forth, why the sterilization should occur?

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: The same reason given here.

turn.speaker: george_e_fruechtenicht
turn.label: Mr. George E. Fruechtenicht
turn.text: Well obviously, the difference that you are suggesting is that John Jones is not the natural parent and guardian of Mary Smith.
In this particular case the mother was the natural parent and guardian of this lady and she asks whether or not the Court would approve.
He did not order anything, he simply approved this.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Could she on her own have the child sterilized?

turn.speaker: george_e_fruechtenicht
turn.label: Mr. George E. Fruechtenicht
turn.text: On her own?
At that particular time obviously, the Court concluded that she could have.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Why did she got to the court?

turn.speaker: george_e_fruechtenicht
turn.label: Mr. George E. Fruechtenicht
turn.text: I do not know.
Perhaps that is simply the context in which this approved.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: What statute do you have in Indiana that authorized the parent to sterilized the child, without the child's permission.

turn.speaker: george_e_fruechtenicht
turn.label: Mr. George E. Fruechtenicht
turn.text: In 1971 there was neither a statute authorizing nor was there a statute barring such a procedure your Honor and that is significant.
That is significant in this particular case.
May I suggest this to you?

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: When you get through your suggestion would you give me the case that the Judge cited?
He did not cite a piece of law about anything.

turn.speaker: george_e_fruechtenicht
turn.label: Mr. George E. Fruechtenicht
turn.text: The case that we have cited is, this is a matter of which is really not to do with sterilization.
This is a matter to you whether or not the doctrine of judicial immunity should apply under these circumstances.

When this petition was presented to this Court, he was duty bound at that particular point to the determine whether he had jurisdiction to decide this particular case, to act in this case that is the issue an approval.

And that source, that power flows from the cases in Indiana and they come basically from Bradley vs. Fisher which says this, “Every Court possesses the power of determining its own jurisdiction both as to the parties and the subject matter of the action.”
It is well settled that when an inferior tribunal is required to ascertain and decide upon facts essential to its jurisdiction, its judgment there on is conclusive against collateral attack.
Unless the want of jurisdiction is apparent on the face of the proceedings.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: My point is where is his jurisdiction?

turn.speaker: george_e_fruechtenicht
turn.label: Mr. George E. Fruechtenicht
turn.text: His jurisdiction, I repeat again your Honor lies in the General Jurisdiction statute as it was pointed out by the District Court which gives him jurisdiction over all other causes, matters and proceedings.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Does the Supreme Court in your state have the same jurisdiction?

turn.speaker: george_e_fruechtenicht
turn.label: Mr. George E. Fruechtenicht
turn.text: I cannot be certain.
It has appellate jurisdiction, I do not think it has original the jurisdiction of this type, it may have.
But may I suggest this, or may I offer this also your Honor that in 1971, the parental consent statutes had not in any way been construed by any Court.
In other words they had not been amended by legislation nor had any Court construed the consent statute so as to prohibit a certain types of surgery.
So, when you say was there a statute permitting a tubal ligation, nor was there a statute permitting the Judge to consent in to appendectomy or a tonsillectomy.
None of that, but on the other hand there was not a statute which said he could not consent to that, he could not issue an approval of such and once again keep in mind this was not an order.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: May I ask a question?

turn.speaker: george_e_fruechtenicht
turn.label: Mr. George E. Fruechtenicht
turn.text: Yes, you may.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Was this petition filed in Court?

turn.speaker: george_e_fruechtenicht
turn.label: Mr. George E. Fruechtenicht
turn.text: This petition was presented to the Judge your Honor and any suggestion that it was not is totally without base.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, that was not my question, is there any record in the Court house that the petition --

turn.speaker: george_e_fruechtenicht
turn.label: Mr. George E. Fruechtenicht
turn.text: No, sir.
I would like to respond that at the later time but I shall do so now.
There has been a suggestion in the Seventh Circuit Court of Appeals but that condition makes it some sort of proceeding that is not the case your Honor.
It is true that this does is not carry a cause number but that is not unusual occurrence.
Approvals of documents which are submitted to Circuit Courts, frequently do not carry any sort of a file marking.

They are not adversary proceedings; example would be, in minor state it is customary before a settlement is approved that a petition is prepared, the minor is absent presented to the Court and although the thing maybe numbered.
There is certainly no adversary proceeding and it is not an adversary cause, simply decided in the absence of the minor.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: But the minor is also represented by counsel, two of them.

turn.speaker: george_e_fruechtenicht
turn.label: Mr. George E. Fruechtenicht
turn.text: No, need not be.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Do they not have a committed appointed for them?

turn.speaker: george_e_fruechtenicht
turn.label: Mr. George E. Fruechtenicht
turn.text: No, sir.
He did not be.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: How can he be present if he is a minor --

turn.speaker: george_e_fruechtenicht
turn.label: Mr. George E. Fruechtenicht
turn.text: His natural guardian your Honor, presents in the form of his mother or his father comes to the Court and under oath advises the Court that she or he thinks that the settlement is proper and the Court approves the settlement.
Same way, yes sir.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: May I follow up my question, if there is no record in the Court.
No record of the date on which this order was entered, how would one have appeal, assume this young woman had (Inaudible) this operation, earlier rather than four years later?

turn.speaker: george_e_fruechtenicht
turn.label: Mr. George E. Fruechtenicht
turn.text: So, far as I know your Honor approvals are not appealed because they are not orders.
This was simply an approval, there was no appeal.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Was this a judicial act?

turn.speaker: george_e_fruechtenicht
turn.label: Mr. George E. Fruechtenicht
turn.text: Yes, sir.
It was certainly the judicial act.
It was presented to the Judge, as a Judge signed by him as Judge.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Suppose the young lady had known on the occasion of what her mother was doing and had objected as vigorously as she could, the Judge nevertheless had entered this consent, would she have had no recourse to appellate courts in Indiana?

turn.speaker: george_e_fruechtenicht
turn.label: Mr. George E. Fruechtenicht
turn.text: Of course that did not happen, did it?
But, supposing if it had.
She would not have had recourse your Honor from the action of the Judge.
She has sued seven people, one of the defendants is the Judge.
She would have her state Court action as she possesses today.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, wait a minute, you are saying today that she does not have recourse against the Judge.

turn.speaker: george_e_fruechtenicht
turn.label: Mr. George E. Fruechtenicht
turn.text: That is correct.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: So, she would not be able to appeal and she would not have any simply approval.

turn.speaker: george_e_fruechtenicht
turn.label: Mr. George E. Fruechtenicht
turn.text: That is correct, it was simply an approval.
This was not on appealable order and there was no other.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: So she would have no recourse whatever.

turn.speaker: george_e_fruechtenicht
turn.label: Mr. George E. Fruechtenicht
turn.text: Against the Judge.
No, sir she would not.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Or anybody else?

turn.speaker: george_e_fruechtenicht
turn.label: Mr. George E. Fruechtenicht
turn.text: Yes, she would.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Whom?

turn.speaker: george_e_fruechtenicht
turn.label: Mr. George E. Fruechtenicht
turn.text: Those people who would have presumed to act to her mother, who would presume that she has (Inaudible) to a State Court action.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: How about the physician?

turn.speaker: george_e_fruechtenicht
turn.label: Mr. George E. Fruechtenicht
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: The surgeon.
But, her consent indemnifies a physician in a hospital?

turn.speaker: george_e_fruechtenicht
turn.label: Mr. George E. Fruechtenicht
turn.text: That of course is an agreement between the mother and surgeon and a contract between the two of them.
I do not think that that binds the daughter.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: I would do not think so.
Does it mean that the mother is eventually, exclusively liable than her --

turn.speaker: george_e_fruechtenicht
turn.label: Mr. George E. Fruechtenicht
turn.text: Exclusively liable?

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Under the indemnification agreement.

turn.speaker: george_e_fruechtenicht
turn.label: Mr. George E. Fruechtenicht
turn.text: I suppose it depends upon whether the indemnification agreement is forcible.
I would not prejudge that your Honor.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Why?

turn.speaker: george_e_fruechtenicht
turn.label: Mr. George E. Fruechtenicht
turn.text: May suggest this also and perhaps I would stop suggesting, and just simply advise what our positions is.
The facts of the case are known to the Court.
The operation did occur, it was not disclosed to this girl by her mother that it was tubal ligation, she was told it was an appendectomy.

The girl married, a couple of years later and approximately four years after the incident occurred sometime in 1975, through investigation it was disclosed that indeed a tubal ligation had occurred, that is when an action was commenced in the Federal District Court under 42 USC 1983.
In which the mother was sued along with Judge, the lawyer, and three doctors and the hospital.

The opinion of the Federal District Court is the one which this petitioner feels should be restored because that opinion deals with this problem, we think appropriately and correctly applies the Doctrine of Judicial Immunity.

The Federal District Judge Ashba (ph) had no difficulty in finding that this being a Court of General Jurisdiction, that Court being entitled to entertain all types of causes, matters and proceedings.
Most specifically undertook this act all be it not in an adversary proceedings, undertook this act with jurisdiction to do so.
He acknowledged that it was not an order, it was simply an approval.
Approvals occur with frequency, that Court summed up, I think.

Well, I would like to read “except when there is clear absence of all jurisdictions over the subject matter, a Judge is entitled to complete immunity to sue based upon his official acts and absolute immunity defeats a suit at the outset so long as the official's actions were within the scope of the immunity.
The allegedly wrongful acts committed by Judge Stump, consisted solely in his approval of the petition filed in this Court by defendant McFarlin.
The Circuit Courts of the Indiana are Courts of General Jurisdiction having a original exclusive jurisdiction in all cases of law on equity whatsoever.

There is jurisdiction in such a Court to hear petitions for tubal ligation, A.L. vs G.R.H. by implication although the Court there held that on the merits the sterilization could not be thus consented to.
But, whether or not Judge Stump’s approval of the petition may in retrospect appear to have been premised on erroneous view of the law.
Judge Stump surely had jurisdiction to consider the petition and to act there on.
Accordingly Judge Stump is closed with absolute judicial immunity and neither he nor his alleged co-conspirators maybe held liable under sections 1983, 1985 or under the Fourteenth Amendment.
The case Your Honors to which the Judge made reference, A.L. vs G.R.H., was a case of first impression in Indiana, decided four years after the Judge entered his approval.
That is 1975.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: That case was after Judge Stump approved.

turn.speaker: george_e_fruechtenicht
turn.label: Mr. George E. Fruechtenicht
turn.text: That is correct, after Judge Stump's approval.
That case was brought because there obviously was a question as to whether or not a parent could consent under the consent statute to have a tubal ligation performed upon a minor child.

In that case a declaratory judgment action was filed and Indiana then determined as matter of policy, the Court of Indiana as a matter of policy that they did not think any body under any circumstances could be sterilized.

It joined a number of other states but once again, that decision, once again did not remove the jurisdiction from the Court of General Jurisdiction from Judge Stump to consider further petitions of this type all it did was say, if somebody walked into Judge Stump today with a petition to have a tubal ligation performed on a minor, he would have to act upon it because he has the jurisdiction to act upon it but his action would be, I am now aware of the fact that in Indiana there is a policy against permitting parents to do so and I must tell you that I cannot approve your petition.

But, the key to this is that he retains jurisdiction and I have suggested in the brief and suggest to you now, the policy which has been established by Bradley v Fisher, Randall v Brigham over a century ago and consistently applied by the Federal Courts down to this time with respect to the application of the doctrine of judicial immunity is similar at least in my view after reading all of these cases to the policy which is employed by Courts when dealing with criminally accused people.
And that is the accused is considered innocent until proved guilty beyond a reasonable doubt.
The policy with respect to judicial immunity is that the Court is presumed to have jurisdiction until it is shown that he acted in clear absence of all jurisdiction over the subject matter.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, Mr. Fruechtenicht, if Judge Stump had done what he did in 1966, after the decision of the Indiana Court in AL against GRH it would had been erroneous, as a matter state law but it would not be in the absence of jurisdiction would it?

turn.speaker: george_e_fruechtenicht
turn.label: Mr. George E. Fruechtenicht
turn.text: That is correct.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: So, your argument would be the same.

turn.speaker: george_e_fruechtenicht
turn.label: Mr. George E. Fruechtenicht
turn.text: My argument would be yes.
But, under those circumstances I would simply say that to assume that a Judge of this experience, under these conditions who would do that is beyond at this my imagination.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: There was no adversary process here and it might very well be that he did not know of that decision.
But, in any event if he had done what he did, quite contrary to the President of AL against GRH, your argument would be precisely the same.

turn.speaker: george_e_fruechtenicht
turn.label: Mr. George E. Fruechtenicht
turn.text: Precisely, and I would say this with respect to the liability your Honor of those additional parties that under those circumstances then, the mother must be construed to be dealing at her parole as the doctors because there are presumed to know the law also.
So, I beg your pardon.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Isn't there a difference between this preceding and the GL whatever the initials are of the other case.
That was suit or a declaratory judgment in which counsel, guardian was appointed and counsel -- there was an adversary proceeding.
There was clearly a jurisdiction to entertain such a suit, this is a petition for approval where there was nobody appointed of any kind, you say approvals are common.
Would you give me some other examples of approvals?
I am just not that familiar.

turn.speaker: george_e_fruechtenicht
turn.label: Mr. George E. Fruechtenicht
turn.text: Right, I have given you the example where by a parent will come in to the Court and simply petition the Court that he wants a sum of money approved by the Court as being reasonable to take care of the minor's injury based upon the parents.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But, that is an ancillary to a pending case.

turn.speaker: george_e_fruechtenicht
turn.label: Mr. George E. Fruechtenicht
turn.text: No, that is ancillary to settling a case, the case may not even have been tried, frequently they are not.
A minor is run over by an automobile.
Separates a broken leg, $2500 is agreed upon, goes in the Court.
The minor never even shows up.
Approvals as far as, your getting at it, I think your Honor, the failure to point a Guardian ad litem for this girl.

I must suggest that in every case where a mother decides to sue her husband and where there are children, those children automatically through the mother come under the EGS of the Court and he makes dispositions of those children's future interests which are extremely important to that child.

To suggest, as I think maybe the logical inference of this suggestion that Guardian ad litem are to be appointed to suggest that an each case where a child is the subject a matter having to do with visitation and custody and its future religious practices in a divorce action.
That that child, each individual child is entitled to a Guardian ad Litem and presumably an attorney would boggle the entire system.
Courts customarily assumed jurisdiction over the children under those circumstances.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Well, is it your position that the state legislature has appointed the natural parents as the Guardian ad Litem for the minor children?

turn.speaker: george_e_fruechtenicht
turn.label: Mr. George E. Fruechtenicht
turn.text: That is correct your Honor in many instances.
As an example also I pointed out in the reply brief, when under age people come and they want to get married and they are under the age of consent.
They can go before the Circuit Court Judge either by written or oral petition and he can approve that under age marriage, there is no file marking.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Is there a statute that provides that?

turn.speaker: george_e_fruechtenicht
turn.label: Mr. George E. Fruechtenicht
turn.text: Yes sir, there is statute which provides it.
But, you Honor that simply establishes the fact that a Judge can function under many, many general circumstances absent which we would consider to be the formality of an adversary proceedings.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: That is what puzzles me, you say these approvals, ex parte approvals are common but each example you give is related to some more or less traditional judicial proceedings.
If the Judge's view of the law were correct here, his approval probably was not necessary.

turn.speaker: george_e_fruechtenicht
turn.label: Mr. George E. Fruechtenicht
turn.text: That is correct.
All I can do is surmise, we have had no evidence in this case your Honor.Surmise that this is the context in which Mrs. McFarlin and her Attorney determined that they wished this consent to be made.
They wished the Court to approve.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Perhaps for the doctors insisted to perform it?

turn.speaker: george_e_fruechtenicht
turn.label: Mr. George E. Fruechtenicht
turn.text: Perhaps, there is no evidence of that, perhaps.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Are you saying, if I followed the last answer that it would have been unnecessary for the Judge to have a evidence to his consent.
The consent of the mother would had been sufficient in Indiana law.

turn.speaker: george_e_fruechtenicht
turn.label: Mr. George E. Fruechtenicht
turn.text: A careful reading of these statutes your Honor does not-- these statutes with respect to consent by the parent do not confer jurisdiction upon the Court, these are not jurisdictional statutes.
They simply permit the parent to consent to surgery, and so the answer to your question would be, yes.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Does not that leave the court in position of performing only a ministerial act?

turn.speaker: george_e_fruechtenicht
turn.label: Mr. George E. Fruechtenicht
turn.text: I do not think so your Honor.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: What judgment does he make?

turn.speaker: george_e_fruechtenicht
turn.label: Mr. George E. Fruechtenicht
turn.text: There was a verified petition presented to him.
This is a very careful in conscientious judge.
This mother was faced with a very real situation at least in her lifetime, and he made a determination that would be for the best interest of the child if these occurred.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Is there any evidence of that?

turn.speaker: george_e_fruechtenicht
turn.label: Mr. George E. Fruechtenicht
turn.text: There is an evidence of the verified petition your Honor.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: I have read the petition, it says very little.

turn.speaker: george_e_fruechtenicht
turn.label: Mr. George E. Fruechtenicht
turn.text: Well, what it did say, it least said.
Remember this is a county of 30,000 people.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: We do not know whether he made any independent inquiry of any kind.

turn.speaker: george_e_fruechtenicht
turn.label: Mr. George E. Fruechtenicht
turn.text: We do not know that he did not either your Honor.
I would presume that he did because of the fact that he has jurisdiction to do so, but the general jurisdiction statute.
I beg your pardon sir?

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Do you think we can act on your presumption?

turn.speaker: george_e_fruechtenicht
turn.label: Mr. George E. Fruechtenicht
turn.text: I would prefer.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Did he take testimony?

turn.speaker: george_e_fruechtenicht
turn.label: Mr. George E. Fruechtenicht
turn.text: I do not know.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Don't you think if he had taken testimony somebody by now would have said so --

turn.speaker: george_e_fruechtenicht
turn.label: Mr. George E. Fruechtenicht
turn.text: The testimony was -- if he did would be by a way of a verifying petition your Honor, which she has a right to accept this.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: My brother says that he read neatly.
There might be some more, I mean for example that child might have done nothing in the world at all, is that not a possibility?

turn.speaker: george_e_fruechtenicht
turn.label: Mr. George E. Fruechtenicht
turn.text: Your Honor.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Is that not a possibility so far as the record in the case is concerned?

turn.speaker: george_e_fruechtenicht
turn.label: Mr. George E. Fruechtenicht
turn.text: Of course it is a possibility.
I must repeat, the issue which we are confronted is whether or not the Doctrine of Judicial Immunity should be applied to this act.
And if there is jurisdiction on the part of this Judge to entertain and approve this petition, it being a judicial act, then he is clearly entitled to the application of the Doctrine.
The policy reasons underlying that particular Doctrine are most important to the continuation of the fearlessness about which the cases like Bradley vs. Fisher talk about.
Thank you.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Are there some states, if you know which require that on an application for sterilization, that a panel of physicians must be a designated to advise the Court.

turn.speaker: george_e_fruechtenicht
turn.label: Mr. George E. Fruechtenicht
turn.text: I think, Indiana would not permit it all but I think Illinois does your Honor.
Sterilization is permitted, I believe in Illinois under these specific statutory circumstances.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Mr. Finley.

turn.speaker: richard_h_finley
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Finley
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court.
Your Honors, I believe that the questioning today indicates what is truly the crux today and that is that the probably the Doctrine of Judicial Immunity need not come in to play in your decision.

The question ask by Mr. Justice Powell was this not merely administrative act as discuss in ex parte Virginia and non judicial act as discussed in several lower Court, federal Court cases probably is going to be the correct and the logical determining decision in this case.

The consent statute which authorized the parent to consent to surgery of a minor child clearly can be read only in the terms of common sense, necessary surgery.Certainly sterilization on a petition as filed by the mother in this instance, is not necessary surgery.
There is a long line of cases which has developed on the kidney transplant cases, for example, that a parent just does not have the power to consent to non therapeutic, none beneficial surgery.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But you would not make the rule of judicial immunity to turn on whether the Judge reached a correct conclusion as to whether the surgery was necessary would not, would you?

turn.speaker: richard_h_finley
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Finley
turn.text: No, your Honor, I would not.
I would have the decision be that the Judge never made a judicial decision.
If the case had been properly presented as in A.L. vs G.R.H., the case was filed with the Court.

The Guardian ad Litem was appointed to represent Linda, if attorneys brief and prepared arguments on each side and the Court made a determination that we will allow sterilization under Indiana and common law as it exists today, then I would say in that instance your Honor that the Judge made a mistake but his is entitled to immunity for his action because he had subject matter and I honestly also believe personal jurisdiction is required.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Are you saying that the principal judicial immunity does not apply to an ex parte and ex parte decision by the Judge.

turn.speaker: richard_h_finley
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Finley
turn.text: Yes, your Honor.
I cannot imagine of an ex-parte decision without some case or matter being properly in front of a Judge.
The examples given by Mr. Fruechtenicht, all were ex parte but they had in front him, the Judge had in front of him some case.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well then you are not saying that the judicial immunity does not apply to an ex parte decision, you are saying he must have a case before him or be it perhaps it maybe decided on an ex parte basis.

turn.speaker: richard_h_finley
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Finley
turn.text: Yes, your Honor.
In that sense that is how I was using ex parte.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: But, you would not rule out the historic power of it.
The Court of the equity to enter ex parte injunction, would you?

turn.speaker: richard_h_finley
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Finley
turn.text: No, your Honor.
But, in the injunction or TRO, Temporary Restraining Order circumstances the statute always provides for notice --.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: In addition there is no adversary proceeding there, is there?

turn.speaker: richard_h_finley
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Finley
turn.text: No, but notice is -- I have never seen a statute authorizing a Temporary Restraining Orders of that type of action or I have never seen an action outside of a statute in an equitable nature, where notice is not given to the party whose property is being restrained or taken away.
And so, that afterwards the parties rights are preserved.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: In a Temporary Restraining Order, certainly the state where I practiced, and which I thought followed the federal rules, up until the mid 60’s when those rules were amended, you could get a Temporary Restraining Order without notice to adverse party, was it had to be returnable in three days.
But, you could get it without notice.

turn.speaker: richard_h_finley
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Finley
turn.text: Yes, but generally speaking your Honor I would submit that instance when it was returnable within that three days before it was made permanent, the party had a right to appear and present his side of the story, assuming that there was an issue on which he wanted evidence presented.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But, what about an improper, wrong decision on the Temporary Restraining Order which was not noticed, and the adverse party did not have notice or that cannot be cured by the time, it is returnable and you have your hearing on the preliminary injunction.

turn.speaker: richard_h_finley
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Finley
turn.text: That is a though question your Honor and my inclination would probably be to say that I would like some kind of qualified immunity, if it were a good faith favor.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: What about, search issuance -- search warrants where there is no criminal case pending, it is just an investigation.

turn.speaker: richard_h_finley
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Finley
turn.text: Again, upon the issuance of that search warrant, the criminal defendant, if he ultimately becomes one, he is going to have a chance in Court to say that he --.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: It may never be any case.

turn.speaker: richard_h_finley
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Finley
turn.text: Well, if no case is filed, he is probably not going to be permanently deprived of any right.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: The officers came into his house and he claims illegally, and he sues the Judge for a gross error.

turn.speaker: richard_h_finley
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Finley
turn.text: I do not believe it is gross error, I think it is a mistake, I think that Judge who issued the warrant ex parte --.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Do you think to make a case out of it, all the Judge has to do is make it a case.
He puts a number on it and puts in the file.

turn.speaker: richard_h_finley
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Finley
turn.text: I think that goes a long way toward making it a judicial act which under the judicial immunity.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, the Judge here had said well I think I would better appoint a Guardian Ad Litem before I pass on this and they did and the Guardian Ad Litem and they gave it a number and the Guardian Ad Litem came in and opposed it and the Judge says, well, I am going to grant it.
Would there be an immunity?

turn.speaker: richard_h_finley
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Finley
turn.text: Yes, your honor.
I think there would be immunity there until the statute says, --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: He would have jurisdiction then to -- perhaps mistakenly but jurisdiction to issue the order.

turn.speaker: richard_h_finley
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Finley
turn.text: Yes, your honor.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Mr. Finley having to give me your case away, because if I understand you, the petition which was filed, did give the Judge the power if he had thought of the wise procedure to appoint a Guardian Ad Litem.
Could he not have done that on the base of this petitions, that I will treat this as a complaint for declaratory judgment upon a guardian?

turn.speaker: richard_h_finley
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Finley
turn.text: No, your Honor.
I do not believe, I have given the case away because the petition was never filed.
There is no file stands.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: You rest on the lack of a number.

turn.speaker: richard_h_finley
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Finley
turn.text: I rest on the total lack -- if you are going to draw a line and say at 'x' point along it --.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Let me ask you this question, I had this very same petition, this very same action, and filed and taken.
Except that was filed in court and a number was put on it, would your case then be gone?

turn.speaker: richard_h_finley
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Finley
turn.text: My inclination is to say that probably it would be but that question is not in front us because in this instance, Linda Sparkman was given absolutely no case, there was absolutely no --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: I know, but my assumption is that she still does not get notice and the same unfortunate consequences all follow.
The only difference is they put a copy on the Clerk's office.

turn.speaker: richard_h_finley
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Finley
turn.text: Well, your Honor, at that point I would say that probably a judicial act occurred and then it would be necessary to determine if under our law of judicial immunity as established by Randall and Bradley and Pierson allows for a determination of jurisdiction with just subject matter or also personal jurisdiction, determination without the presence of personal jurisdiction.
My feeling is that the language used in each one of this three cases, although, in Bradley v Fisher, they used the term subject matter jurisdiction.
They really mean personal jurisdiction because each of the instances, personal jurisdiction was present.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: What do you mean by personal jurisdiction?

turn.speaker: richard_h_finley
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Finley
turn.text: Jurisdiction over the persons, so as to preserve that person's right of appeal before the total deprivation of his due process rights.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, now that answer does not necessarily make a good deal of sense to me.
Perhaps it is my fault rather than yours.

If the person has a right to appeal from the order even though he may be outside of this state and never have been served with process or in the state and never notified of it, does that, by your definition confer personal jurisdiction.

turn.speaker: richard_h_finley
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Finley
turn.text: No, I would say that it does not, I would say that the same rights, the same basic right to appeal is going to be preserved if he had knowledge, so I think you are correct your Honor.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Let me give you one other case that has been turning over in my mind.Supposing the allegation in the petition instead of being that she was retarded and promiscuous, had rather been that she was infected with a malignant cancer and that a medical judgment of the doctor was that, it should be removed by this procedure and then the Judge did exactly what he did here and acting in all good faith, do you think he was right, he did not appoint a guardian, he did not file a paper in the court or he did not do any thing else but later on it turns out they were wrong.
Would he be a liable?

turn.speaker: richard_h_finley
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Finley
turn.text: I would say your Honor that it would probably have been technically not a judicial act and probably technically under my theory there could, if one could show damages be a cause of action --Yes, sir.
Against the Judge.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: That leads to wonder, are you not to, I think this is relevant to your immunity argument -- are you not if we agreed with you and the case went forward, are you not going to have in showing damages, are you not going to have show that his act was really sort of an important factor in this procedure and that perhaps the doctor required a judicial consent or that he really was not an instrumental in producing this consequences?

turn.speaker: richard_h_finley
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Finley
turn.text: I think that there would be incumbent upon us in a trial to convince the jury, that the Judge had some reason beyond the normal judicial reason for billing what he did.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well and also that Judge's action was approximate cause of the operation.

turn.speaker: richard_h_finley
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Finley
turn.text: Yes, your Honor.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, why do you suppose anybody went to the judge?
Because the doctor wanted it or what?

turn.speaker: richard_h_finley
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Finley
turn.text: Because the doctor --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: So the doctor required a judicial act.

turn.speaker: richard_h_finley
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Finley
turn.text: I think the doctor wanted the protection of an instrument signed by the Judge.
I think that Linda, the facts would show, was in the hospital a few weeks earlier, supposedly for the purpose of having her appendix removed and then was discharged.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: So, at least of the act, the parties who were acting here wanted a judicial act, something that would pass for one.

turn.speaker: richard_h_finley
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Finley
turn.text: Well, they wanted a piece of paper with the Judge's name on it, I believe.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: And sometimes that is judicial act, is it not?

turn.speaker: richard_h_finley
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Finley
turn.text: I think it can become a judicial act if the Judge treats it such as but where the Judge did absolutely none of the things that a Judge does, when particularly deciding contrary to the rights of an individual, it is no longer a judicial act.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Well, it could actually be a TRO then, TRO may impede a very important act that causes damage to someone and whether the particular Court jurisdiction requires a three day return or five day, nevertheless, the TRO could be granted on the same kind of representations on petitions as represented here, could it not?

turn.speaker: richard_h_finley
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Finley
turn.text: Well, it would be filed in Court your Honor, and would ultimately become the basis of an appeal, could become the basis of an appeal, whereas when it is done in total secrecy there is no way --.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Well, a TRO, if you call it, total secrecy or in chambers or ex-parte, a TRO is usually entered that way, is it not?

You go in to the judge in chambers and you present an affidavit and an order and if he is persuaded by the affidavit, and the representation was made, he will perhaps restrain some act that causes someone a great deal of damage.

turn.speaker: richard_h_finley
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Finley
turn.text: But, your Honor, temporary restraining order is that temporary.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: It might be fatal.
Suppose it is a Temporary Restraining Order that restrains the giving of the blood transfusion, do you remember Jehovah’s witnesses and the patient dies as a result of it in a three day period.

turn.speaker: richard_h_finley
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Finley
turn.text: I would think your Honor that, that is clearly a…

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: We will resume there at one o' clock.
You may continue Mr. Finley.
Before you do, let me give you a corollary to the question I put at the noon break.
I think there, I had a man in Jehovah’s witness in the hospital who declined the --, there was injunction to enjoin the giving of a your blood transfusion and he died.

Now, suppose you have the opposite it is the blood transfusion, hospital petitions for authority to give the blood transfusion in order to save the man’s life, and Judge having jurisdiction, let's assume for the moment, generally issues, the order requiring him to take the blood transfusion, that could be a battery, I assume would it not?

turn.speaker: richard_h_finley
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Finley
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Now, if you had a kind of situation you have here, is the jurisdiction immunity or not?

turn.speaker: richard_h_finley
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Finley
turn.text: I would say that there would be immunity had the matter properly had been petitioned and filed in the Court of the Judge who made this order.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Let us suppose it is an ex-parte.

turn.speaker: richard_h_finley
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Finley
turn.text: Well, even without a file in the Court.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Transfusion is given an hour after the paper is presented to the Judge and the Judge has it in his pocket, petition filed in the clerk's office at all --

turn.speaker: richard_h_finley
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Finley
turn.text: But, it is contemplated that it would be filed.I would say if it was contemplated that it would be filed, my inclination would be say that instance that there would be immunity --Since I would at that point, I think it was probably a judicial act.
I think that differs from the instant case because there was no contemplation I believe your Honor in a filing of the case in Sparkman’s Court.
I think that that goes to the real basis of the justification for the doctrine of judicial immunity has this Court has previously said it.
In 1967 when this Court, I think last considered judicial immunity in Pierson v Ray.
It indicated that they realized that immunity was unnecessary fact for a Judge in order to be able to act.
But, this Court also recognized in Bradley and in Randall that there is a counter balance inherent within the judicial system that protects the litigant, and that is the right to appeal.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: How do you distinguish your colleague's example of the settlement of a minor's personal injury claim, which I think it takes place fairly early often in most states, where the minor's case is not even then filed say against the automobile driver, the train company.

turn.speaker: richard_h_finley
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Finley
turn.text: I think your Honor, in that instance there are specific rules and specific statutes authorizing the Judge to approve of a minor's settlement in that type of instance whereas in our case there was no statute authorizing.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: But, those are two different kinds of distinctions, one is your saying that there was no substantive authorization for the Judge to act the way he did and the other is you are saying there really was not even any judicial act or case before it.

turn.speaker: richard_h_finley
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Finley
turn.text: Well, in the instance of your example, I think there was a case presented to the Judge.
Although, in manner outside of the filing, perhaps something was filed in this Court.
I am sure he spoke through the Court's record when he approved of the settlement.
At least in our state the Court would have spoken through its records at that point.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Would it be filed?

turn.speaker: richard_h_finley
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Finley
turn.text: In the instance that Mr. Justice Rehnquist.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: The case where it had not reached the Court yet and the settlement is made, is that filed in the Court because when they say it is filed, under what?

turn.speaker: richard_h_finley
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Finley
turn.text: I have only handled one your Honor.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Those are not filed.

turn.speaker: richard_h_finley
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Finley
turn.text: In the state of the Indiana, I have only handled one and I did file it in the Circuit Court, I titled it Ray, the settlement of minor child so and so.
It was filed in Court and the Court on a docket sheet made a record.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: That brings me to the other point, what about the petition is pointed, it did not need to sign this at all.

turn.speaker: richard_h_finley
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Finley
turn.text: My feeling is that probably he needs.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Can you do better than your feeling.

turn.speaker: richard_h_finley
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Finley
turn.text: Well, I think the law is that the decisions to date, I had said that it must be judicial act.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Is not the law that an operation of the minor is controlled by the parent.

turn.speaker: richard_h_finley
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Finley
turn.text: I would say that the law in state of Indiana is that a parent may consent to necessary surgery of a minor.
But, Mr. Justice Marshall I would submit that this was not the type of necessary surgery.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Do you have a statute or case in what Nobody is saying that is a statute or case, that says, “Yes, you know on this point.”

turn.speaker: richard_h_finley
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Finley
turn.text: I would say that A.L. vs G.R.H. which was decided in 1975 by the Indiana Court of Appeals, said en banc says that that statute does not give a parent the consent that the authority to consent to a sterilization on a minor.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: But the general one is still true?

turn.speaker: richard_h_finley
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Finley
turn.text: That the general statute is still true.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Tonsillectomy for example.

turn.speaker: richard_h_finley
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Finley
turn.text: Tonsillectomy, I would have no question that a parent could consent to a Tonsillectomy of a minor child because that is necessary.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And is under action of a Court or a Judge or anything else.

turn.speaker: richard_h_finley
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Finley
turn.text: That is right, in need not go to a Court and that is why getting back.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: The Judge in this case assumes that what is his doing is just perfunctory.

turn.speaker: richard_h_finley
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Finley
turn.text: I think your Honor no one.

turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: He assumed that he has authority to do it.

turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Finley

turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: I assume that he did.

And I still do not know that it was wrong.

turn.speaker: richard_h_finley
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Finley
turn.text: But, the manner in which it was done in a non-judicial.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: But then the plaintiff, he did not file that.

turn.speaker: richard_h_finley
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Finley
turn.text: Not only that he did not file it.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall

turn.speaker: richard_h_finley
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Finley

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall

turn.speaker: richard_h_finley
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Finley
turn.text: That he did not make a record of his approval.
That he did not let his approval be known to Linda so that she could appeal the act and appeal the approval and prevent the act of permanent sterilization from being performed.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: When he grants that consent of the mother who is by law the Guardian Ad Litem has he not given constructive notice to the minor?

turn.speaker: richard_h_finley
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Finley
turn.text: Your Honor, in Indiana trial rule 17, the Indiana trial rules state that the Guardian Ad Litem that a natural parent in effect, if she is the Guardian Ad Litem, this is in extrapolation of what the statute says, if the interest of the Guardian Ad Litem would be contrary then the Court must appoint a new Guardian Ad Litem to represent.

Now, clearly when a mother on extremely untutored to say the least allegations that her child is maybe somewhat retarded although, progressing normally through her school, when she turns to a Court and makes these types of allegations, clearly, she is no longer acting in the best interest of her child.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: What you are saying then, are not you, is that the Judge made a judicial error.
He did not have that law or rule that you refer in to mind.

turn.speaker: richard_h_finley
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Finley
turn.text: I cannot believe that it was a judicial error when he did nothing that a Judge does.

It was an error in a administrative capacity perhaps because I think if the Judge knew of this statute, the consent statute and he thought that he was following the consent statute dicta or demand, then it was not necessary for him to do anything and his signature on that piece of paper was a nullity.
There was no reason for it to leave, if it had even been there.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: How was your client injured?

turn.speaker: richard_h_finley
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Finley
turn.text: As a result, of the Judge's actions?

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Yeah.

turn.speaker: richard_h_finley
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Finley

I think that a Judge sitting on a bench --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: I am not too sure if you have no any right to charge him a conspiracy at all.

turn.speaker: richard_h_finley
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Finley

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: That means that in conspiracy you can not have people.

turn.speaker: richard_h_finley
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Finley

turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, can we not decide this case without using words like that?

turn.speaker: richard_h_finley
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Finley

turn.text: Mr. Finley you bother me somewhat with your distinction between necessary and unnecessary surgery.

What about your person these days and when you say tonsillectomy is necessary, I question, that there is an awful lot of medical opinion these days, then in certain cases.
Tonsillectomy is not all necessary.

turn.speaker: richard_h_finley
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Finley
turn.text: Mr. Justice Blackmun, I appreciate the determining what is necessary surgery is sometimes difficult.

But, the twin who is asked to give up a kidney to save his twin brother is not benefited.
Courts have and I frankly do not agree with the decisions in all but one instance that I been able to find, Courts have said that that is not necessary surgery.

So, I think that the Court can look factually maybe through psychiatrist's testimony as to what the cosmetic surgery might do for the benefit of the child who needs it or on whom it is ought to be performed.
Perhaps psychiatrist could testify as to beneficial nature to that child.

But, I think in the example, the instant case clearly anybody can see that sterilization is not beneficial or therapeutic or necessary in order to prevent Linda Sparkman from having children, there could been other things done.
If in fact, that were the --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Did I get the impression from something you said that this consent approval of the Judge really was not necessary at all?

turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Finley

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger

turn.speaker: richard_h_finley
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Finley

But, I think he completely evaded it and did not treat it in any sense.
Witness of fact that he did nothing to protect Linda, he did what he did in total secrecy.
It can be shown, and will be shown factually if we ever get to that point that he had lots of opportunities to tell Linda Sparkman that she was sterilized but he never took those opportunities.
If I may just --.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Let me just take a pause there --supposing he had taken all of those opportunities, would that have made this a judicial act?

turn.speaker: richard_h_finley

But, all I am saying is that I think maybe you can infer from the opportunities at the end what his real intent was, that was evading the judicial act nature of it from the beginning.
A Judge owes a duty to protect the people brought in front of him, just as much he owes a duty to penalize the people brought in front of him.
But, getting back to the rationale.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: You concede that people were brought in front him.

turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Finley

If he had been acting to the Judge --.

turn.label: Unknown Speaker

Then they said do you think we ought to give notice, and he says no it really will not help because she is retarded or whatever he said, they talked it all through.
He nevertheless entered the order.
It would still not have been a judicial act.

turn.speaker: richard_h_finley
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Finley
turn.text: I do not think it would been a judicial act and I know it would have been clearly outside of any jurisdiction he might had have.
The Indiana law did not permit, getting back to the consent and I think this is important and I not mentioned it to date and petitioners have not.
There were statutes on the books in Indiana in 1971 authorizing sterilization of institutionalized individuals.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But this is not an institutionalized individual.

turn.speaker: richard_h_finley
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Finley
turn.text: That is precisely what I am saying and through statutory construction, and the Seventh Circuit so held in this case and I think it is common statutory construction at all that through the expressed permission of sterilization of certain of its citizens, Indiana is saying you cannot sterilize --

turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Are you saying that there is no way under the law of the Indiana where had there been good grounds to do so that this child could have been sterilized?

turn.speaker: richard_h_finley
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Finley
turn.text: In 1971, the only way that this child could have been sterilized, is if she were an institutionalized mentally retarded child and if the procedures were specific --.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: Even if she had fatal cancer in her tubes.

turn.speaker: richard_h_finley
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Finley
turn.text: I would say in that instance I would go around the statute, no matter what it might say and if I were the Judge, in ordering the sterilization.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But you think the law would never permit it under any circumstances, I just wonder if that is right, Judge Ashba (ph) did not think that.
He is a pretty good Indiana lawyer.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: He practiced in Indiana for a number of years before taking the bench, did he not?

turn.speaker: richard_h_finley
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Finley
turn.text: Judge Ashba (ph), I recognize, felt that also -- what you are saying that in --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And really, the Indiana case you cite does not say that, that says the particular reason given there was insufficient even though the parents sincerely believed it was.

turn.speaker: richard_h_finley
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Finley
turn.text: In 1975, A.L versus G.R.H. was decided and --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But that case does not hold it is never permissible.

turn.speaker: richard_h_finley
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Finley
turn.text: Your Honor the other statutes were removed from the books by that time.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: But, he thought he was talking about the substantive Indiana law, which really is not the question we are talking about.

turn.speaker: richard_h_finley
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Finley
turn.text: Yes, your Honor.
I believe that that is what Judge Ashpa said.

But, I do not believe that is a correct analysis of the prior Supreme Court decisions which preserve the right to a litigant to appeal and the manner in which the sterilization was approved by Judge Stump, totally destroyed and intentionally destroyed any right to appeal.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Essentially then we must disagree with Judge Ashpa on the Indiana jurisdiction consent.

turn.speaker: richard_h_finley
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Finley
turn.text: Yes, your Honor.

I would say so, there are other ways in which it could be decided and 42 USC 1988, which says that state law should be applied rather than Federal law and Immunity and I think it is clear that state law in Indiana of immunity is that a Court before he has jurisdiction must have a subject matter and personal jurisdiction.

Again, I think it is clear from the fact instance, in the instant case that the Judge had no personal jurisdiction even though he might, I would not concede it But, he might argumentatively have subject matter jurisdiction.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: In Pierson v Ray, we certainly did not look to Alabama Law rather than Federal Law in deciding whether Judges had absolute immunity.

turn.speaker: richard_h_finley
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Finley
turn.text: No, I think that as I understand it, the Federal Law is that Lynch vs Johnson, Monroe versus Pepe, all say that Federal Law applies generally speaking but if the state law is more protective of the rights of the individual, then I think it is questionable under 1988 if perhaps the state law is not the law of judicial immunity which is to be applied.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Mr. Finley, I am sorry but I just have to ask one another question, you said it is clear that they did not have personal jurisdiction in this case.

turn.speaker: richard_h_finley
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Finley
turn.text: Guardian Ad Litem was the one --.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: But, you are saying that there was no personal jurisdiction until a guardian was appointed.

turn.speaker: richard_h_finley
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Finley

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun

turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Finley

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker

turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger

turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Finley

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger

turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Finley

turn.speaker: richard_h_finley
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Finley

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Weren't that (Inaudible) or whatever?

turn.speaker: richard_h_finley
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Finley
