turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: We are talking about something quite different from that, suppose it was a 17-year-old girl who was a Christian science convert and protested against surgery, could the parents consent to having her appendix removed?

turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Finley
turn.text: I would say that the Court would have jurisdiction to hear that case, look at getting back to Mr. Justice Blackmun’s questioning, look at the reasons behind the request, determine if under the Indiana statute of a parent having the power to consent a necessary surgery to look at it and look closely and if he made an err, he is still entitled to immunity.
There is no question because he is done something that a judge does after he is assumed jurisdiction in a Judge like manner.
But, comparing it again with the fact situation we have got that analogy does not even come close --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Did he not think, he was doing Judge's work?

turn.speaker: richard_h_finley
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Finley

turn.text: This is a Judge in a rare community is it right?

By billing quite a few, that people just drop in at the street and check with the Judge.
Is that not right?

turn.speaker: richard_h_finley
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Finley
turn.text: Yes, your Honor they do.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well in order to for him to lose his immunity, does he have to say, “I am acting as a Judge or not acting as a Judge.”

turn.speaker: richard_h_finley
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Finley
turn.text: He has to act as a Judge in order to protect --.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: I mean, is that not in his mind that?
It is he, that is the one the seeking immunity.

turn.speaker: richard_h_finley
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Finley
turn.text: Mr. Fruechtenicht began at the very beginning explaining that Judge Stump is an experienced Judge.
He had been there a heck of a long time and he had been.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: There are many of experienced Judges who have made mistakes.

turn.speaker: richard_h_finley
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Finley
turn.text: Your Honor, if this were a simple mistake after he had assumed jurisdiction or if there had been arguably subject matter personal jurisdiction.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, did he not think he assumed jurisdiction.

turn.speaker: richard_h_finley
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Finley
turn.text: I do not think he thought he had jurisdiction.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: You do not know one where the other --.

turn.speaker: richard_h_finley
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Finley
turn.text: I know Judge Stump fairly well and I doubt very seriously if he thought he had jurisdiction.
I think he probably thought that this girl should be sterilized.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Why did he sign and said that he was a Judge, did he not say that?

turn.speaker: richard_h_finley
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Finley
turn.text: He did not type that.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: But, he signed and I assume he read it.
And nothing you will say contradicts my assumption that he read it.

turn.speaker: richard_h_finley
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Finley
turn.text: I assume he read it also.

And I assume that when he read it, he saw that the right appropriate and this girl one of our basic constitutional rights was being taken away, and he as a Judge knew that the statutes of the state of the Indiana required him to do lots of things, if he was going to act as a Judge and he did not owe one of those things that the statutes of the state of Indiana requiring to do.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, you would make that argument, I take it and whether he had jurisdiction to enter this order or not.

turn.speaker: richard_h_finley
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Finley
turn.text: Yes, your Honor I would.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: So, that Judge Ashba said he had jurisdiction but you would say, well, even if he did, he did not act as a Judge.
He did not do any of the things that the judge would do.

turn.speaker: richard_h_finley
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Finley
turn.text: Your Honor, as a predicate to the Doctrine of Judicial Immunity this Court has always stated, as it was stated in England in the 1600, it must be a judicial act taken within the judge's jurisdiction.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And you also say he had no jurisdiction.

turn.speaker: richard_h_finley
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Finley
turn.text: I also say that he had no jurisdiction, I agree with this Seventh circuit analysis.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Now, would you say that, just so I get your position, suppose the statutes of Indiana said no district judge shall have any jurisdiction what so ever to approve or purport approve a sterilization.
And then a petition is filed with a Judge, the Judge looks at it, he gives it a number and he approves it.
It is utterly wrong and he should have known he was wrong, immunity or not?

turn.speaker: richard_h_finley
turn.label: Mr. Richard H. Finley
turn.text: No immunity, that would be waived for (Inaudible) and clearly it is in violation of a subject matter jurisdiction as most liberally defined and no immunity.
But, here that question need not be reached, if it were reached, I would still say that all three of the Supreme Court cases, previously decided would deny immunity.
If not, then as I said earlier, any Judge of General Jurisdiction can do anything and that cannot be justified with the previous rational granting immunity and if I may say one further thing.

The last case that this Court really decided, I think in giving blank immunity to prosecutors in Imbler v. Patchman, is not contrary to what I am saying, because again the Court was very careful in pointing out that what that Judge or prosecutor did was within his prosecutorial function and what Judge Stump did was in no way within his judicial functioning.
He completely over look and intentionally so his judicial functions.
Thank you.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Very well, thank you gentlemen.
The case is submitted.
